thread.title: 'World's fattest tigers' because unlikely tourist attraction after overfeeding at zoo
thread.title_full: 'World's fattest tigers' because unlikely tourist attraction after overfeeding at zoo

author: Chris Baynes
title: 'World's fattest tigers' because unlikely tourist attraction after overfeeding at zoo
text:
News 'World's fattest tigers' because unlikely tourist attraction after overfeeding at zoo People poked fun at the portly Siberian tigers after pictures went viral showing them looking more like well-fed tabbies as they lolled around Share Porky tigers have caused a stir on social media (Photo: AsiaWire) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Tubby tigers have have become a tourist attraction after piling on the pounds stuffing their faces. 
Social media users have poked fun at the real-life fat cats after pictures showed them looking more like well-fed tabbies as they lolled around at a Chinese zoo . 
Some joked that the Siberian tigers had over indulged at the country's Spring Festival, which centres on huge family family feasts. 
Others expressed concern for the the portly beasts, but zookeepers have assured them the big cats overeat in the winter months to survive harsh winters of their natural habitat. The tigers overeat in winter to keep warm (Photo: AsiaWire) 
The tigers photographed also face freezing conditions at Siberia Tiger Park in northeast Chinaâ€™s Harbin province, where temperatures call fall as low as 20C. 
The tigers will gradually slim down as winter thaws and temperatures climb in the summer. Read More Fat bear channels his inner Yogi and stands on two legs to give back a really good scratch The big cats naturally slim down as summer arrives (Photo: AsiaWire) 
Siberian Tiger Park, which covers a million square meters of land, was set up to breed and house the largest of the big cats. 
It is home to about 800 Siberian tigers, an endangered species with an estimated 500 living in the wild - mostly in Russia. Like us on Facebook
